articles.title: MAY 7TH PRESENTS: THE GREAT BAY AREA ASTRONOMICAL AUCTION
articles.summary: This article outlines a series of upcoming astronomical events for May and June, including the 8th Annual Great Bay Area Astronomical Auction on May 7th featuring a flea market, silent auction, and traditional auction. It also details several field expeditions for astronomical observation, board meetings followed by introductory astronomy classes, and mentions the Riverside Telescope Makers Convention.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: This article details the history of the SJAA Astronomical Auction, which was established eight years prior to fund a permanent observing site and telescope for its members. The auction has seen significant growth and success, offering a wide array of astronomical items. To improve efficiency, a new Swap-Meet event has been introduced this year for specialized items.

articles.title: Swap-Meet
articles.summary: This article details an upcoming Swap-Meet auction, an important fundraising event for the SJAA observatory fund. It emphasizes the need for participants to pre-register items, particularly big-ticket items like telescopes for the silent auction, and explains the bidding and registration process. The event is highlighted as a fun gathering featuring well-known attendees and an experienced auctioneer.

articles.title: APRIL 16TH GRANT RANCH STAR PARTY
articles.summary: The article apologizes for not listing the April 16th Grant Ranch Star Party in the previous bulletin. The author humorously takes responsibility for the subsequent week-long cloud cover, joking that a 'rain dance' performed to prevent an unannounced star party got out of hand and wiped out the entire new moon week for observing.

articles.title: THE 1988 MESSIER MARATHON
articles.summary: The article reports on two significant amateur astronomy events: the 1988 SJAA Messier Marathon, where participants observed over 50 Messier Objects despite cloud cover and location challenges, and the upcoming 20th Annual Riverside Telescope Makers Conference. The conference, held Memorial Day weekend at Camp Oaks near Big Bear City, celebrates its anniversary with special programs, numerous telescope displays, and commercial exhibitors, attracting enthusiasts despite being close to a full moon.

articles.title: IT'S BACK TO COE PARK
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is planning a field expedition for astronomical observation at Henry Coe Park on May 14th. The article provides detailed directions to the park, including specific instructions for accessing the locked observing site gate with combination 4565, and advises late arrivals to park outside and hike in to find a spot.

articles.title: JUNE 4TH SPEAKER NEEDED
articles.summary: The organization is actively seeking a volunteer speaker for its June 4th General Meeting. Suggested topics for presentations include telescope making, deep-sky observing, planet watching, and specifically an analysis of the upcoming, potentially best-in-a-lifetime Mars opposition. Interested members are encouraged to contact Tom Ahl or Jim Van Nuland.

articles.title: GROWING PAINS
articles.summary: The Ephemeris editor, now in their fifth year, is experiencing "growing pains" due to increasing membership, content contributions, and personal time constraints, which sometimes leads to typos in the rushed newsletter production. To alleviate this and enhance content, the editor is seeking volunteers to serve as "reporters at large" to cover SJAA events and also requests a donation of PageMaker software to improve the newsletter's format.

articles.title: THE PRETORIA EYEPIECE BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: The Pretoria eyepiece, a new ocular design, deliberately introduces reverse coma to cancel aberrations in fast f/4 parabolic telescopes, significantly enhancing image quality. Now in production by University Optics, it has received strong praise for delivering sharp, coma-free, and high-contrast views, particularly in f/4 and f/3.8 instruments. Despite some design changes from its prototype and potential focusing challenges, the reviewer highly recommends it for its comfort, wide field, and overall value in suitable telescopes, emphasizing a 'try before you buy' approach.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY BOB MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article provides updates on Comet Liller (1988a) and the newly discovered Comet Levy (1988e), including their current visibility, orbital characteristics, and discovery details by David Levy. It then delves into the history of awards and prizes for comet discoveries, from 19th-century gold medals to the modern Tuthill Comet Award. The piece concludes by exploring the complex and often debated criteria for distinguishing between amateur and professional comet discoverers.

articles.title: MAY STARRY NIGHTS
articles.summary: The article outlines astronomical events for May, focusing on the Eta Aquarid meteor shower which peaks on May 4th but faces reduced visibility due to the full moon. It also describes a rare 'Blue Moon' occurring on May 31st, defined as the second full moon in a calendar month, and briefly touches on the actual visual phenomenon of a blue-colored moon.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This 'Ephemeris' article details celestial events and optimal observing opportunities for the month of May. It provides positions and magnitudes for several minor planets, including Euterpe, Eunomia, Ariadne, and Vesta, which are reaching opposition. The article also highlights lunar occultation and graze events, and especially notes that May offers exceptional viewing of Venus due to its peak brightness, high northern track, and distinct phase changes.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This article is an advertisement for a used 10-inch Coulter F/4.5 Newtonian reflector telescope, priced at $2000. The telescope comes with a massive, portable German equatorial mounting, multiple eyepieces, various finderscopes, and astrophotography accessories including a drive corrector and telextender. It is described as a very stable system suitable for astrophotography, with contact details provided for Dan Beck.

articles.title: C90 SPOTTING SCOPE
articles.summary: This is an advertisement for a Celestron C90 spotting scope (orange) in mint condition, offered for sale by Hal Zangari. The package includes the scope, star diagonal, 12mm, 18mm, and 30mm eyepieces, porro prism, Barlow lens, 3-21mm zoom lens eyepiece, and a Celestron photographic tripod. The seller is accepting the 'Best Offer'.

articles.title: SHUTTLE TESTING CONTINUES
articles.summary: Recent Space Shuttle testing included a successful short-duration solid motor joint test at 120Â°F and a liquid main engine test series confirming design life with 55 starts and 7.5 hours of operation. A new curved pole escape system has been selected and is slated for installation in Discovery by July. However, insulation problems on solid motors for the next launch have consumed all contingency time, likely delaying the August 4 launch date.

articles.title: WHICH SPACE STATION WILL BE APPROVED?
articles.summary: Congress has blocked NASA's plans to issue a request for proposals to lease space on a commercial orbiting facility, demanding that NASA justify its choice between a traditional space station, a leased commercial platform, or the Spacelab shuttle module. This legislative intervention makes the current year a critical one for the future approval and direction of the space station program, highlighting a conflict over national space policy.

articles.title: NASA'S PLANS TO REVITALIZE SPACE SCIENCE
articles.summary: NASA's strategy to revitalize space science involves two main phases: first, launching already developed payloads like the Hubble Space Telescope, Galileo, Ulysses, Mars Observer, and Magellan. Second, NASA aims to initiate a new mission each fiscal year, proposing projects such as an Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility, a global climate study, a Titan mission, an Earth-viewing platform, a lunar orbiter, and a flyby mission to comet Wild-2.

articles.title: HERMES SPACEPLANE DEFINITION PROGRAM BEGINS
articles.summary: Europe has initiated the full-scale definition phase for its Hermes spaceplane program, with plans to build two flight models. The first unmanned flight is projected for mid-1997, followed by manned missions commencing in the first half of 1998.

articles.title: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES TAKE SPACE PROGRAM POSITIONS
articles.summary: This article outlines the differing positions of several presidential candidates, including George Bush, Jesse Jackson, Michael Dukakis, and Albert Gore, on the U.S. space program. Their stances cover topics such as the re-establishment of the Space Council, support for the space station and Mars exploration, unmanned missions, militarization of space, budget priorities, and international cooperation. The candidates express varied levels of commitment to ambitious space goals, cost-effectiveness, and the role of space in national competitiveness.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article reviews three Vista Points along Hwy 280 in the San Carlos area, suggested by Russ Kirk of the San Mateo Astronomical Society, as potential astronomical observing sites. It details each site's accessibility, elevation, parking, horizon views, and light pollution levels, noting common issues like other parkers' headlights, wind, and fog. The authors encourage astronomers to try these unique highway locations, despite initial appearances, as they offer viable spots for stargazing, with Site #1 being the darkest and Site #2 the brightest but highest.

articles.title: The San Jose Astronomical Association's
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association is hosting its 8th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction and Swap-Meet on Saturday, May 7th. The event, taking place at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, will open doors at 1:00 PM, with a swap-meet from 2:00-5:00 PM and the auction running from 6:00-10:00 PM. Participants are requested to pre-register items for auction.

articles.title: The 8th annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction
articles.summary: The 8th annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction is approaching, inviting individuals to sell astronomical and telescope-making related items. Pre-registration is encouraged by mailing a form to assign bidder/seller and item numbers, with a portion of the selling price (minimum 10%) going to SJAA for public education in astronomy. The event will feature a Flea Market/Swap-Meet in the afternoon and a main auction from 6:00 pm, with a silent bid option for high-ticket items like complete telescopes.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS TO THE AUCTION
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to an auction event located at 16011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd, specifying the route from HWY 17 (880) South. Doors open at 1:00 pm, with a $1.00 donation requested for registration to buy or sell, and refreshments will be provided. It also includes a pre-registration form for the 1988 SJAA Auction, outlining fields for bidder and item details.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on a wide range of astronomical topics and serving as "Indoor Star Parties" for members. These meetings, which cover interests like astrophotography and telescope making, take place on the 1st Saturday of each month and include detailed directions and times.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and accessories, with activities ranging from outdoor observing and astrophotography slideshows to SJAA board meetings and introductory astronomy workshops.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These events take place at various designated locations, ranging from sites close to San Jose to destinations as far as Yosemite National Park. Attendees should consult the EPHEMERIS for specific star party locations.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a popular observing site for Bay Area amateur astronomers, located 70 miles south of San Jose. It hosts regular gatherings during New Moon weekends for deep sky observing and astrophotography, often attracting 50-100 telescopes during summer. The article also provides directions to the park and contact information for the San Jose Astronomical Association.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), outlining different membership options and their respective fees, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T' (Sky & Telescope), and 'Junior (Under 18)'. It provides instructions for submitting the form and payment to the treasurer, Jack Peterson, and includes contact information for the association.
